key_title: Key to the species of Schoenus

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Monocotyledons
Key to the genera of Cyperaceae

source.author: Wilson, K.L.
source.title: Cyperaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Wilson, K.L. (1994). Cyperaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Inflorescence head-like or consisting of only 1–5 spikelets in 1 or 2 small clusters
Inflorescence elongated, with spikelets clustered at several often distant nodes

Small, soft-textured leafy, tufted annuals, or small, mat-forming or decumbent perennials, or submerged aquatics; if erect, culms no more than 12 cm long; mouth of leaf-sheath and margins of glumes always glabrous
Erect perennials, ± rigid, shortly rhizomatous or tufted; culms mostly more than 12 cm high, if less then mouth of leaf-sheath and/or margins of glumes hairy
Fertile glumes 5–9 mm long
Fertile glumes less than 5 mm long
Submerged aquatic or occasionally small, tufted plant on margins of water; nut smooth or minutely reticulate
Dryland tufted or very shortly rhizomatous plants; nut not smooth
Inflorescence head-like; plants annual, forming small tufts; nut reticulate-pitted to trabeculate, glabrous
Inflorescence of 1–3 spikelets
Perennial, very shortly rhizomatous, forming low, deep-rooted tussocks or mats; nut transversely wrinkled, pubescent near apex
Annual, tufted; nut reticulate-pitted, glabrous
Tufted annuals
Small mat-forming or decumbent perennials
Hypogynous bristles absent or several, minute
Hypogynous bristles 5 or 6, from shorter than nut to slightly exceeding it (nut faces evenly trabeculate or reticulate)
Nut faces reticulate-pitted
Nut faces with 2 central columns of large pits and laterally smooth or minutely trabeculate
Anthers 1.0–3.2 mm long; nut reticulate-pitted to trabeculate; glumes red-brown to blackish
Anthers 0.5–0.8 mm long; nut coarsely and strongly reticulate; glumes straw-coloured to dark red-brown
Leaves much exceeding culms; culms erect, no more than 2.5 cm long; damp alpine and subalpine sites
Leaves shorter than culms; culms erect or decumbent, usually more than 3 cm long; plants of lowlands or margins of mountain streams, but never alpine
Anthers 0.8–1.0 mm long; hypogynous bristles 3–6, not plumose, shorter than nut; culms decumbent, leafy at nodes
Anthers 1.5–1.7 mm long; hypogynous bristles 6, plumose, about as long as nut; culms erect, nodeless
Inflorescence a single spikelet
Inflorescence a head-like cluster of spikelets (rarely a second smaller cluster in S. ericetorum)
Mouth of leaf-sheath ciliate or woolly
Mouth of leaf-sheath glabrous
Spikelet 8–22 mm long; fertile glumes 8–16 mm long; hypogynous bristles scale-like
Spikelet 3–5 mm long; fertile glumes 2.7–4 mm long; hypogynous bristles plumose
Involucral bracts at least twice as long as inflorescence, to 8 cm long
Involucral bracts less than twice as long as inflorescence (often shorter than it), to 2.5 cm long
Stamens 4–6; nut 1.9–2.5 mm long
Stamens 3; nut 1.3–1.5 mm long
Mouth of leaf-sheath long-ciliate; glumes 6–11, lowest 4–8 empty
Mouth of leaf-sheath glabrous or sparsely and minutely ciliolate; glumes 5–7,lowest 3–5 empty
Small, soft-textured leafy, tufted annuals, or small, mat-forming or decumbent perennials; if erect, culms no more than 10 cm long
Rigid, erect perennials (or S. apogon annual), shortly rhizomatous or tufted; culms mostly 10–125 cm high, if less then culms scabrous (S. moorei) or leaves very numerous and filiform (S. tesquorum)
Decumbent or loosely mat-forming slender perennial; nut surface faintly pitted or reticulate or smooth
Erect, tufted annuals; nut surface pitted, reticulate, or trabeculate
Anthers 0.5–0.7 mm long; nut faces with 2 central columns of large pits, laterally smooth or trabeculate
Anthers 1.0–3.7 mm long; nut faces evenly reticulate-pitted or trabeculate

Hypogynous bristles 5 or 6, setaceous, shorter than or equalling nut; inflorescence with a head-like cluster of 6–16 spikelets at uppermost node with 1–4 smaller clusters below; glumes red-brown to blackish
Hypogynous bristles absent or several, minute; inflorescence with 2–4 distant clusters of 1–5 spikelets; glumes straw-coloured to red-brown
Leaves obvious, leaf-blades well-developed, to 30 cm long
Leaves not obvious, leaf-blades to 3 cm long or reduced to small bracts on sheaths
Nut transversely wrinkled, hairy; culms scabrous; possibly not in Victoria, see note under genus description
Nut smooth or minutely pitted-reticulate or longitudinally striate and trabeculate, glabrous; culms smooth
Annual, leafy but without numerous filiform leaves at base; hypogynous bristles 5 or 6, shorter than to equalling nut
Perennial, with numerous filiform leaves at base of plant; hypogynous bristles several minute or absent
Mouth of leaf-sheath villous or woolly
Mouth of leaf-sheath glabrous
Leaf-sheaths very dark red-brown to black, minutely scabrous; glumes 7–11 per spikelet
Leaf-sheaths yellow-brown to red-brown, smooth; glumes 4–6 per spikelet
Glumes glabrous; nut smooth to faintly reticulate, white to grey
Glumes ciliate or woolly at least near apex; nut papillose or wrinkled, red-brown
Glumes 7–9 per spikelet; fertile glumes 7–10 mm long; nut wrinkled; mouth of leaf-sheath with margins not overlapping
Glumes 5 or 6 per spikelet; fertile glumes 5–7 mm long; nut papillose; mouth of leaf-sheath with margins overlapping
